title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote effective congressional oversight, and enhance accountability of Congress and agencies to the public. Congress recognizes the need for accurate information to ensure laws are implemented efficiently and fairly. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "economically significant rule," and "independent evaluation" to ensure transparency and accountability in regulatory decisions. The Comptroller General will evaluate the data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules, including strengths and weaknesses that may impact the rulemaking process. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule within specific timeframes, including an independent evaluation. The Comptroller General must submit a report on an economically significant rule within specific timeframes, including an independent evaluation of the rule's benefits, costs, and alternative approaches. The Comptroller General must submit a report on an economically significant rule, evaluating its costs, benefits, alternative approaches, and implications of any changes made in the final rule. The Comptroller General evaluates economically significant rules, including costs, benefits, and implications of changes in the final rule. Agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General, who prioritizes requests for review based on rulemaking notices. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published 3 years after the effective date.
